entry.title: Inverse CDF Sampling
entry.content:
Inverse CDF sampling is a method for obtaining samples from both discrete and continuous probability distributions that requires the CDF to be invertible. The method assumes values of the CDF are Uniform random variables on [0,1][0, 1][0,1]. CDF values are generated and used as input into the inverted CDF to obtain samples with the distribution defined by the CDF.

Discrete Distributions

A discrete probability distribution consisting of a finite set of NNN probability values is defined by,

{p1,p2,…,pN}     (1), \{p_1, p_2,\ldots,p_N\}\ \ \ \ \ (1), {p1​,p2​,…,pN​}     (1),

with pi≥0, ∀ip_i \geq 0, \ \forall ipi​≥0, ∀i and ∑i=1Npi=1\sum_{i=1}^N{p_i} = 1∑i=1N​pi​=1. The CDF specifies the probability that i≤ni \leq ni≤n and is given by,

P(i≤n)=P(n)=∑i=1npi, P(i \leq n)=P(n)=\sum_{i=1}^n{p_i}, P(i≤n)=P(n)=i=1∑n​pi​,

For a given CDF value, UUU, Equation P(n)P(n)P(n) can always be inverted by evaluating it for each nnn and searching for the value of nnn that satisfies, P(n)≥UP(n) \geq UP(n)≥U. It follows that generated samples of U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \textbf{Uniform}(0, 1)U∼Uniform(0,1) will have distribution (1)(1)(1) since the intervals P(n)−P(n−1)=pnP(n)-P(n-1) = p_nP(n)−P(n−1)=pn​ are Uniformly sampled.

Consider the distribution,

{112,112,16,16,112,512}     (2) \left\{\frac{1}{12}, \frac{1}{12}, \frac{1}{6}, \frac{1}{6}, \frac{1}{12}, \frac{5}{12} \right\} \ \ \ \ \ (2) {121​,121​,61​,61​,121​,125​}     (2) It is shown in the following plot with its CDF. Note that the CDF is a monotonically increasing function.

A sampler using the Inverse CDF method on the distribution specified in (2)(2)(2) implemented in Python is shown below.

import numpy

n = 10000
df = numpy.array([1/12, 1/12, 1/6, 1/6, 1/12, 5/12])
cdf = numpy.cumsum(df)

samples = [numpy.flatnonzero(cdf >= u)[0] for u in numpy.random.rand(n)]

The program first stores the CDF computed from each of the sums P(n)P(n)P(n) in an array. Next, CDF samples using U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \textbf{Uniform}(0, 1)U∼Uniform(0,1) are generated. Finally, for each sampled CDF value, UUU, the array containing P(n)P(n)P(n) is scanned for the value of nnn where P(n)≥UP(n) \geq UP(n)≥U. The resulting values of nnn will have the distribution (2)(2)(2).

The figure below favorably compares generated samples and (2)(2)(2),

A measure of convergence of the samples to the target distribution can be obtained by comparing the cumulative moments of the distribution computed from the samples with the target value computed analytically. For the distribution (2)(2)(2). In general for a discrete distribution the first and second moments are given by,

μ=∑i=1Nipiσ2=∑i=1Ni2pi−μ2, \begin{aligned} \mu & = \sum_{i=1}^N ip_i\\ \sigma^2 & = \sum_{i=1}^N i^2p_i - \mu^2, \end{aligned} μσ2​=i=1∑N​ipi​=i=1∑N​i2pi​−μ2,​

In the following two plots the cumulative values of μ\muμ and σ\sigmaσ computed from the samples generated by distribution (2)(2)(2) using Inverse CDF Sampling are compared with the target values using the equations above. The first shows the convergence of μ\muμ and the second the convergence of σ\sigmaσ. Within only 10310^3103 samples both μ\muμ and σ\sigmaσ computed from samples is comparable to the target value and by 10410^4104 the values computed from samples and the target values are indistinguishable.

The number of operations required for generating samples using Inverse CDF sampling from a discrete distribution will scale O(NsamplesN)O(N_{samples}N)O(Nsamples​N) where NsamplesN_{samples}Nsamples​ is the desired number of samples and NNN is the number of terms in the discrete distribution.

It is also possible to directly sample distribution (2)(2)(2) using the multinomial sampler from numpy,

import numpy

n = 10000
df = numpy.array([1/12, 1/12, 1/6, 1/6, 1/12, 5/12])
samples = numpy.random.multinomial(n, df, size=1)/n

Continuous Distributions

A continuous probability distribution is defined by the PDF, fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x), where fX(x)≥0,∀xf_X(x) \geq 0, \forall xfX​(x)≥0,∀x and ∫fX(x)dx=1\int f_X(x) dx = 1∫fX​(x)dx=1. The CDF is a monotonically increasing function that specifies the probability that X≤xX \leq xX≤x, namely,

P(X≤x)=FX(x)=∫xfX(w)dw. P(X \leq x) = F_X(x) = \int^{x} f_X(w) dw. P(X≤x)=FX​(x)=∫xfX​(w)dw.

Proof

To prove that Inverse CDF sampling works for continuous distributions it must be shown that,

P[FX−1(U)≤x]=FX(x)     (3), P[F_X^{-1}(U) \leq x] = F_X(x) \ \ \ \ \ (3), P[FX−1​(U)≤x]=FX​(x)     (3),

where FX−1(x)F_X^{-1}(x)FX−1​(x) is the inverse of FX(x)F_X(x)FX​(x) and U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \textbf{Uniform}(0, 1)U∼Uniform(0,1).

A more general result needed to complete this proof is obtained using a change of variable on a CDF. If Y=G(X)Y=G(X)Y=G(X) is a monotonically increasing invertible function of XXX then,

P(X≤x)=P(Y≤y)=P[G(X)≤G(x)].     (4) P(X \leq x) = P(Y \leq y) = P[G(X) \leq G(x)]. \ \ \ \ \ (4) P(X≤x)=P(Y≤y)=P[G(X)≤G(x)].     (4)

To prove this note that G(x)G(x)G(x) is monotonically increasing so the ordering of values is preserved for all xxx,

X≤x⟹G(X)≤G(x). X \leq x \implies G(X) \leq G(x). X≤x⟹G(X)≤G(x).

Consequently, the order of the integration limits is maintained by the transformation. Further, since y=G(x)y=G(x)y=G(x) is invertible, x=G−1(y)x = G^{-1}(y)x=G−1(y) and dx=dG−1dydydx = \frac{dG^{-1}}{dy} dydx=dydG−1​dy, so

P(X≤x)=∫xfX(w)dw=∫yfX(G−1(z))dG−1dzdz=∫yfY(z)dz=P(Y≤y)=P[G(X)≤G(x)], \begin{aligned} P(X \leq x) & = \int^{x} f_X(w) dw \\ & = \int^{y} f_X(G^{-1}(z)) \frac{dG^{-1}}{dz} dz \\ & = \int^{y} f_Y(z) dz \\ & = P(Y \leq y) \\ & = P[G(X) \leq G(x)], \end{aligned} P(X≤x)​=∫xfX​(w)dw=∫yfX​(G−1(z))dzdG−1​dz=∫yfY​(z)dz=P(Y≤y)=P[G(X)≤G(x)],​

where,

fY(y)=fX(G−1(y))dG−1dy f_Y(y) = f_X(G^{-1}(y)) \frac{dG^{-1}}{dy} fY​(y)=fX​(G−1(y))dydG−1​

For completeness consider the case where Y=G(X)Y=G(X)Y=G(X) is a monotonically decreasing invertible function of XXX then,

X≤x⟹G(X)≥G(x), X \leq x \implies G(X) \geq G(x), X≤x⟹G(X)≥G(x),

it follows that,

P(X≤x)=∫xfX(w)dw=∫yfX(G−1(z))dG−1dzdz=∫yfY(z)dz=P(Y≥y)=P[G(X)≥G(x)]=1−P[G(X)≤G(x)] \begin{aligned} P(X \leq x) & = \int^{x} f_X(w) dw \\ & = \int_{y} f_X(G^{-1}(z)) \frac{dG^{-1}}{dz} dz \\ & = \int_{y} f_Y(z) dz \\ & = P(Y \geq y) \\ & = P[G(X) \geq G(x)] \\ & = 1 - P[G(X) \leq G(x)] \end{aligned} P(X≤x)​=∫xfX​(w)dw=∫y​fX​(G−1(z))dzdG−1​dz=∫y​fY​(z)dz=P(Y≥y)=P[G(X)≥G(x)]=1−P[G(X)≤G(x)]​

The desired proof of equation (3)(3)(3) follows from equation (4)(4)(4) by noting that U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \textbf{Uniform}(0, 1)U∼Uniform(0,1) so fU(u)=1f_U(u) = 1fU​(u)=1,

P[FX−1(U)≤x]=P[FX(FX−1(U))≤FX(x)]=P[U≤FX(x)]=∫0FX(x)fU(w)dw=∫0FX(x)dw=FX(x). \begin{aligned} P[F_X^{-1}(U) \leq x] & = P[F_X(F_X^{-1}(U)) \leq F_X(x)] \\ & = P[U \leq F_X(x)] \\ & = \int_{0}^{F_X(x)} f_U(w) dw \\ & = \int_{0}^{F_X(x)} dw \\ & = F_X(x). \end{aligned} P[FX−1​(U)≤x]​=P[FX​(FX−1​(U))≤FX​(x)]=P[U≤FX​(x)]=∫0FX​(x)​fU​(w)dw=∫0FX​(x)​dw=FX​(x).​

Example

Consider the Weibull Distribution. The PDF is given by,

fX(x;k,λ)={kλ(xλ)k−1e(−xλ)kx≥00x<0,     (5) f_X(x; k, \lambda) = \begin{cases} \frac{k}{\lambda}\left(\frac{x}{\lambda} \right)^{k-1} e^{\left(\frac{-x}{\lambda}\right)^k} & x \geq 0 \\ 0 & x < 0, \end{cases} \ \ \ \ \ (5) fX​(x;k,λ)={λk​(λx​)k−1e(λ−x​)k0​x≥0x<0,​     (5)

where k>0k>0k>0 is the shape parameter and λ>0\lambda>0λ>0 the scale parameter. The CDF is given by,

FX(x;k,λ)={1−e(−xλ)kx≥00x<0. F_X(x; k, \lambda) = \begin{cases} 1-e^{\left(\frac{-x}{\lambda}\right)^k } & x \geq 0 \\ 0 & x < 0. \end{cases} FX​(x;k,λ)={1−e(λ−x​)k0​x≥0x<0.​

The CDF can be inverted to yield,

FX−1(u;k,λ)={λln(11−u)1k0≤u≤10u<0 or u>1. F_X^{-1}(u; k, \lambda) = \begin{cases} \lambda\ln\left(\frac{1}{1-u}\right)^{\frac{1}{k}} & 0 \leq u \leq 1 \\ 0 & u < 0 \text{ or } u > 1. \end{cases} FX−1​(u;k,λ)={λln(1−u1​)k1​0​0≤u≤1u<0 or u>1.​

In the example described here it will be assumed that k=5.0k=5.0k=5.0 and λ=1.0\lambda=1.0λ=1.0. The following plot shows the PDF and CDF using these values.

The sampler implementation for the continuous case is simpler than for the discrete case. Just as in the discrete case CDF samples with distribution U∼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \textbf{Uniform}(0, 1)U∼Uniform(0,1) are generated. The desired samples with the Weibull distribution are then computed using the CDF inverse. Below an implementation of the sampler in Python is listed.

import numpy

k = 5.0
λ = 1.0
nsamples = 100000

cdf_inv = lambda u: λ * (numpy.log(1.0/(1.0 - u)))**(1.0/k)
samples = [cdf_inv(u) for u in numpy.random.rand(nsamples)]

The following plot compares a histogram of the samples generated by the sampler above. The fit is quite good. The subtle asymmetry of the Weibull distribution is captured.

The first and second moments for the Weibull distribution are given by,

μ=λΓ(1+1k)σ2=λ2[Γ(1+2k)−(Γ(1+1k))2], \begin{aligned} \mu & = \lambda\Gamma\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right) \\ \sigma^2 & = \lambda^2\left[\Gamma\left(1+\frac{2}{k}\right)-\left(\Gamma\left(1+\frac{1}{k}\right)\right)^2\right], \end{aligned} μσ2​=λΓ(1+k1​)=λ2[Γ(1+k2​)−(Γ(1+k1​))2],​

where Γ(x)\Gamma(x)Γ(x) is the Gamma function.

The following two plots compare the cumulative values of μ\muμ and σ\sigmaσ computed from Inverse CDF Sampling of distribution (5)(5)(5) with the target values from the equations above. The first shows the convergence of μ\muμ and the second the convergence of σ\sigmaσ. Within only 10310^3103 samples both μ\muμ and σ\sigmaσ computed from samples are comparable to the target values and by 10410^4104 the values computed from samples and the target values are indistinguishable.

Performance

Any continuous distribution, fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x), can be approximated by the discrete distribution, {fX(xi)Δxi}N\left\{f_X(x_i)\Delta x_i \right\}_N{fX​(xi​)Δxi​}N​ for i=1,2,3,…,Ni=1,2,3,\ldots,Ni=1,2,3,…,N, where Δxi=(xmax−xmin)/(N−1)\Delta x_i=(x_{max}-x_{min})/(N-1)Δxi​=(xmax​−xmin​)/(N−1) and xi=xmin+(i−1)Δxix_i = x_{min}+(i-1)\Delta x_ixi​=xmin​+(i−1)Δxi​. This method has disadvantages compared to using Inverse CDF sampling on the continuous distribution. First, a bounded range for the samples must be assumed when in general the range of the samples can be unbounded. The Inverse CDF method can sample an unbounded range. Second, the performance for sampling a discrete distribution scales O(NsamplesN)O(N_{samples}N)O(Nsamples​N) while sampling the continuous distribution is O(Nsamples)O(N_{samples})O(Nsamples​).
entry.summary: Inverse CDF sampling is a method for obtaining samples from both discrete and continuous probability distributions that requires the CDF to be invertible. The method assumes values of the CDF are Uniform random variables on [0,1][0, 1][0,1]. CDF values are generated and used as input into the inverted CDF to obtain samples with the distribution defined by the CDF.
